snippet: With the police arresting half as many people and giving more than 90 percent fewer tickets, some residents were relieved while others feared for their safety.
abstract: New York City police officers, for two consecutive weeks, have been ignoring minor criminal offenses and parking violations so completely that only 347 summonses were issued in one-week period, down from 4,077 in same period year earlier; stark numbers reflect ongoing tension between officers and Mayor Bill de Blasio.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Al Baker, Ann Farmer, J. David Goodman, Winnie Hu, Nate Schweber and John Surico.

lead_paragraph: With the police arresting half as many people and giving more than 90 percent fewer tickets, some residents were relieved while others feared for their safety.

headline.main: Life in New York City, Where Arrests Are Down and Tickets Are Rarities
headline.print_headline: Snapshot of City as Some Officers Turn a Blind Eye
